did.unittitle: UW-Milwaukee Institute of Visual Arts Records, 1962-2016

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. Institute of Visual Arts

physdesc.label: Quantity
physdesc.extent: plus additions of 7 cubic ft. (7 boxes) and 231 digital files (5.3 GB)

extref.corpname: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries, Archives Department

did.abstract: Records of the Institute for Visual Art (Inova), formerly the UWM Art Museum, including information on holdings, exhibits, and administration. The records include correspondence, planning reports, promotional materials, exhibit details and exhibit catalogues, documenting the development of the art collection and management of the art museums and galleries. Also included are exhibition files, which provide details on a wide range of works from emerging student talent, to established local artists, to prominent international exhibits.

bioghist.p: The UW-Milwaukee Art Museum was "established to house and administer the art collections of the University and the exhibition programs in the Fine Arts Galleries, in the Art History Galleries, and in the Museum Galleries in Vogel Hall." All of the art collections on campus were to be moved to a renovated Vogel Hall that would become the University Art Museum. However, due to budget constraints in 1980-1981, only a portion of Vogel Hall became available for housing some of the art collections. At this time, the deans of the School of Fine Arts and College of Letters & Sciences agreed that the UWM Art Museum would become a separate entity that would administer all of UWM's art collections, but not necessarily house everything in the same location. The museum opened to the public in 1983.

In 1996, the name of the University Art Museum was changed to the Institute for Visual Arts or Inova. The mission of the new institute remained the same. In 2007, the Institute for Visual Arts relocated to UWM's Kenilworth Building. The institute remained at the Kenilworth building until Fall 2016, when the Peck School of the Arts discontinued support.

bioghist.head: Directors of the UWM Art Museum
Directors of the Institute for Visual Art

scopecontent.p: The collection contains the records of the Institute for Visual Arts (Inova), formerly the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) Art Museum. The institute is tasked with administering, collecting, and exhibiting UWM's art museum in several campus galleries. More detailed scope and content notes are provided at the series level in the content list.

arrangement.p: The records of the UW-Milwaukee Institute for Visual Arts are arranged in the following two series. More detailed arrangement notes are provided at the series level in the contents list.
The collection contains two additional accessions:

otherfindaid.p: A spreadsheet with file-level information on the electronic records is available in the Archives department. The spreadsheet contains information on original file name, file size, date of modification of original file, original image size, and file format. Additional technical metadata is available; consult an archivist for more information.
A detailed finding aid for accession 2015-042 is available in the Archives.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material in the UWM Libraries

archref.unittitle: UW-Milwaukee Institute of Visual Arts Accession Files

accessrestrict.p: Electronic files must be viewed on computers in the Archives using the access copies. Contact an archivist for more information.
The file in box 25 is permanently restricted. Contact an archivist for more information.
There are no access restrictions on the remaining materials, and the collection is open to all members of the public in accordance with state law.

userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming with the laws of libel, privacy, and copyright which may be involved in the use of this collection (Wisconsin Statutes 19.21-19.39).

acqinfo.p: The Institute of Visual Arts transferred the first accession in February 2008 (accession 2007-042) and the second accession in April 2008 (accession 2007-051).
Accession 2015-042 was received from the Peck School of Arts' Dean's Office and separated from Accession 2015-041 in May 2016. Accession 2016-011 was transferred to the Archives in August 2016.

processinfo.p: Ashley Von Ruden, Nicholas Roche, and Charles Welborn processed accessions 2007-042 and 2007-051 from June 2011-June 2012 (Brad Houston supervised). Brad Houston added electronic images from accession 2007-042 in June 2013. Ashlie Biddle minimally processed accession 2015-042 in May 2016 (Brad Houston supervised). Alison Sielaff minimally processed accession 2016-011 in November 2016 (Brad Houston supervised).

phystech.p: As of November 29, 2016, all electronic files were accessible on a Intel Core i5-4570 CPU (3.20 GHz, 4 GB RAM) running Windows 7 Enterprise, with Service Pack 1. Software used to access the files includes Windows Picture and Fax Viewer, Windows Media Player, and Notepad.
The collection includes records in the following file formats:

Access copies for TIFFs were created by Pixillion Image Converter as JPEG File Interchange Format [.jpg] and were viewable in Windows Picture and Fax Viewer in the same software environment as of June 7, 2013.

scopecontent.p: This series comprises most of the collection. The records include exhibit planning documents, promotional material, artist correspondence, photographs, slides, and various other documents detailing when, where, and how exhibits were set up. These records also include loan forms and often describe works of art on display. Some exhibits files also include a copy of the catalogue produced.

Exhibits were frequently changed, allowing for dozens of exhibitions per year. Reoccurring student and faculty exhibits were created to display talented campus artists and in order to satisfy some degree requirements. Other events, such as College for Kids, are part of a university-wide community outreach effort to engage local schoolchildren.

arrangement.p: The series is arranged chronologically. Folders were named based on the exhibition, which described the main artist, the main theme, or both. Exhibits would frequently change, so it is not unusual to find similar promotional material available in neighboring folders, as flyers might promote several upcoming exhibitions at once.

scopecontent.p: The series includes the operational files of the UWM Art Museum. These documents include insurance claims, accession files, loan requests, committee minutes, planning reports, news releases, schedules, calendars, and miscellaneous correspondence. Folders also detail the donations and gifts of art, materials and money to the UWM Art Museum over the years.

Also included in this series is information regarding two ongoing exhibition series, Fiber R/Evolution and the Women's Autobiographical Artists' Books (WAAB). These exhibitions took place over multiple years, included juried sections, and were often curated in collaboration with other institutions. The Fiber R/Evolution files include correspondence with over 50 artists and an extensive and detailed jury process. The WAAB files include correspondence with 75 women artists and numerous photographs and slides.

arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by folder heading. These records describe different aspects of managing the Art Museum and include numerous case files and donor correspondence, organized in a last name, first name format.
Two ongoing exhibitions, Fiber R/Evolution and the Women’s Autobiographical Artists’ Books (WAAB), are split into two subgroups, administrative and artist correspondence, and arranged alphabetically.

did.abstract: Exhibition files from the Institute of Visual Arts, 1979-2015, including event calendars, catalogs, and other publicity.

The majority of the accession consists of files related to artists and exhibits from INOVA, including curator notes, exhibit planning, art images, exhibit images, and exhibit publications. A small amount of material is also included on the administration of INOVA, including directors’ correspondence, advisory board minutes, records from the annual Nohl Fellowship awarded by INOVA, and strategic planning documents. The digital files include video of and played in exhibits at INOVA, as well as photos of artwork and exhibitions.
